description: This show explores the foundational concepts and workings of Azure SQL. We start by defining why you might decide to implement a hosted database in Azure SQL vs an on-premise solution; detailing some of the benefits of moving to Azure SQL. We then describe some of the more advanced benefits of using Azure SQL like using Resource Groups, Geo-Restore, Point-In-Time Restore, and Self-Service Restore. Finally they take a look at the performance tiers as well as Database Throughput Units or DTUs.
name: Azure SQL
subtitle: Relational Database-as-a-Service

episodes.description: In this segment, Daniel and Don give a general overview of what you can expect in the upcoming episodes. They cover what the show's about, the target audience, what will be covered overall, and other topics.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.071 --> 00:00:07.980
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07.980 --> 00:00:12.436
In this segment we're gonna take a look at
the upcoming Microsoft Azure SQL show that

3
00:00:12.436 --> 00:00:14.583
we have lined up for you here at ITProTV.

4
00:00:14.583 --> 00:00:16.703
And joining me today to
help us guide through that,

5
00:00:16.703 --> 00:00:18.488
well it's none other than Mr. Don Pezet.

6
00:00:18.488 --> 00:00:19.393
How's it going today Don?

7
00:00:19.393 --> 00:00:20.990
>> It's going great Daniel, and

8
00:00:20.990 --> 00:00:23.885
just excited to kick off
another new series on ITProTV.

9
00:00:23.885 --> 00:00:27.337
Now, if you haven't heard about Microsoft
Azure SQL, let's start there, and

10
00:00:27.337 --> 00:00:28.757
we'll talk about what it is, and

11
00:00:28.757 --> 00:00:31.379
we'll get a chance to see what
we're going to be doing here.

12
00:00:31.379 --> 00:00:34.304
Microsoft Azure SQL is
a hosted database service, or

13
00:00:34.304 --> 00:00:37.099
relational database service
from Microsoft, and

14
00:00:37.099 --> 00:00:41.330
it's really cool because databases
have become so important to companies.

15
00:00:41.330 --> 00:00:42.539
You put your data in, and

16
00:00:42.539 --> 00:00:46.350
you expect to get your data back out when
you need it and you expect it to be fast.

17
00:00:46.350 --> 00:00:50.525
So a lot of organizations have to worry
about when they build the database making

18
00:00:50.525 --> 00:00:53.826
it reliable, making it available,
making it nice and fast and

19
00:00:53.826 --> 00:00:55.156
keeping it maintained.

20
00:00:55.156 --> 00:00:57.852
And thatâ€™s a lot of work and
can be quite expensive.

21
00:00:57.852 --> 00:01:01.602
With Azure SQL, we can get
Microsoft to do the work for us.

22
00:01:01.602 --> 00:01:04.850
They'll host the database on
their servers up in Azure cloud.

23
00:01:04.850 --> 00:01:06.289
They'll maintain the servers.

24
00:01:06.289 --> 00:01:09.091
If there's a fault,
like a hard drive fails or something,

25
00:01:09.091 --> 00:01:12.695
their network operations center catches
it, gets in there and repairs it.

26
00:01:12.695 --> 00:01:17.117
They do all the leg work for us,
and we get to focus on our data.

27
00:01:17.117 --> 00:01:18.997
I need a table with some data in it.

28
00:01:18.997 --> 00:01:20.356
I don't care about
the underlying database.

29
00:01:20.356 --> 00:01:22.213
Microsoft's already dealt with that for
me.

30
00:01:22.213 --> 00:01:24.094
I can throw that in there,
get it up and going.

31
00:01:24.094 --> 00:01:27.614
Now you can actually get a lot of control
on the database if you want it, or

32
00:01:27.614 --> 00:01:29.659
you can let Microsoft have that control.

33
00:01:29.659 --> 00:01:33.578
It's up to you, but if you're one of those
people that just needs a database and

34
00:01:33.578 --> 00:01:36.211
wants it to be as reliable and
available as possible,

35
00:01:36.211 --> 00:01:38.450
Microsoft Azure SQL is
a great way to do that.

36
00:01:38.450 --> 00:01:39.506
>> Yeah, sounds awesome, Don.

37
00:01:39.506 --> 00:01:44.357
Now who exactly would be the demographic
that we're focusing here with Azure SQL?

38
00:01:44.357 --> 00:01:46.917
>> So, there's actually a few
different types of people.

39
00:01:46.917 --> 00:01:50.027
Back in the day, we used to just say,
well DBA is database administrators.

40
00:01:50.027 --> 00:01:54.528
But the whole point of Azure SQL is
that you don't have to be a DBA anymore.

41
00:01:54.528 --> 00:01:59.011
So the Azure SQL product is great for
people like system admins, right?

42
00:01:59.011 --> 00:02:02.131
In the past, you might have been
responsible for building up a physical

43
00:02:02.131 --> 00:02:05.260
server to be able to put SQL on there and
then turn it over to the dev team.

44
00:02:05.260 --> 00:02:07.617
Now, you can just reach out and
provision it in Azure.

45
00:02:07.617 --> 00:02:09.938
And so
sys admins can really benefit from this.

46
00:02:09.938 --> 00:02:13.853
But developers can benefit from it also,
because you might need a SQL database and

47
00:02:13.853 --> 00:02:17.843
you don't want to mess around the Windows
server operating system under the hood.

48
00:02:17.843 --> 00:02:19.515
You don't want to do updates.

49
00:02:19.515 --> 00:02:21.036
You don't want to be saddled with that.

50
00:02:21.036 --> 00:02:21.755
You're a developer.

51
00:02:21.755 --> 00:02:22.812
You want to write your product.

52
00:02:22.812 --> 00:02:23.766
You need a database, but

53
00:02:23.766 --> 00:02:26.459
you don't want to be involved in
the interworkings of that database.

54
00:02:26.459 --> 00:02:28.514
You just need a place to put your data.

55
00:02:28.514 --> 00:02:30.391
Azure SQL works out great for you too.

56
00:02:30.391 --> 00:02:34.107
So it starts to fall into
what we call dev ops, right?

57
00:02:34.107 --> 00:02:37.147
Where you might be a developer,
you might be operations, or

58
00:02:37.147 --> 00:02:38.708
you might be tasked with both.

59
00:02:38.708 --> 00:02:42.273
Then this show's really gonna work out
well for you, cuz we can show how you can

60
00:02:42.273 --> 00:02:45.315
use Azure SQL and not have to worry
about the nitty gritty details.

61
00:02:45.315 --> 00:02:49.631
Just let it be done with, and as your
organization grows, if you're an internet

62
00:02:49.631 --> 00:02:53.945
startup and you're getting rapid growth,
you can dial up these databases to get

63
00:02:53.945 --> 00:02:58.283
higher performance and far exceed what
you can do with on-premises equipment.

64
00:02:58.283 --> 00:03:02.355
So, really, any of those types of roles,
this show is gonna work out well for you.

65
00:03:02.355 --> 00:03:04.319
>> Excellent.
Now that we know who should be watching

66
00:03:04.319 --> 00:03:06.121
this show or
might be interested in this show,

67
00:03:06.121 --> 00:03:07.843
what is it exactly that we're gonna cover.

68
00:03:07.843 --> 00:03:11.437
Give us some idea of what we're
gonna see in the upcoming shows.

69
00:03:11.437 --> 00:03:14.480
Right, I've kind of structured the
episodes to be broken up into five parts,

70
00:03:14.480 --> 00:03:17.494
and in the beginning we're just going
to talk about implementing Azure SQL.

71
00:03:17.494 --> 00:03:19.583
How do I create that database server.

72
00:03:19.583 --> 00:03:21.031
How do I create the database on it.

73
00:03:21.031 --> 00:03:24.247
How do I get connected to that data
base so I can use the darn thing?

74
00:03:24.247 --> 00:03:25.268
We're gonna start out there.

75
00:03:25.268 --> 00:03:29.110
So if you know absolutely zero
about Azure SQL you'll be fine..

76
00:03:29.110 --> 00:03:30.526
That's where we're gonna start.

77
00:03:30.526 --> 00:03:35.463
But after that, creating the database
is one part, using it is another.

78
00:03:35.463 --> 00:03:36.879
And that's where we're gonna
break into other things.

79
00:03:36.879 --> 00:03:39.364
We'll take a look at how
to maintain the databases,

80
00:03:39.364 --> 00:03:41.630
which actually is really
easy inside of Azure.

81
00:03:41.630 --> 00:03:44.230
But there's some things we can
do to help improve performance.

82
00:03:44.230 --> 00:03:45.642
We're gonna see how to optimize and

83
00:03:45.642 --> 00:03:48.430
troubleshoot our database in
the event that we're having problems.

84
00:03:48.430 --> 00:03:51.924
If we're running queries and they're
just not running fast, we can try and

85
00:03:51.924 --> 00:03:52.588
find out why.

86
00:03:52.588 --> 00:03:55.388
We're gonna take a look at
how we manage our data,

87
00:03:55.388 --> 00:03:59.457
which is going to include things like
backing up and restoring the data,

88
00:03:59.457 --> 00:04:03.948
as well as doing bulk imports or exports
of data, all sorts of good stuff there.

89
00:04:03.948 --> 00:04:05.863
And then lastly we're
gonna talk about security.

90
00:04:05.863 --> 00:04:10.028
How we secure our Azure databases to make
sure that they are not a weak point,

91
00:04:10.028 --> 00:04:14.585
because it's a rare week that goes by that
we don't worry about some company having

92
00:04:14.585 --> 00:04:15.452
a data breach.

93
00:04:15.452 --> 00:04:16.683
You don't wanna be that company.

94
00:04:16.683 --> 00:04:19.167
So we'll talk a little bit
how to lock those down.

95
00:04:19.167 --> 00:04:19.783
>> Awesome.

96
00:04:19.783 --> 00:04:24.071
Now Don, I know that a lot, well I know
for certain that Microsoft has a SQL exam.

97
00:04:24.071 --> 00:04:28.007
Is this show going to map toward that
exam, or is it something different?

98
00:04:28.007 --> 00:04:29.790
>> This one is going to be a little
something different, right?

99
00:04:29.790 --> 00:04:32.862
Most of the shows here on ITPro TV
do focus on kind of working

100
00:04:32.862 --> 00:04:36.638
towards a certification, but
this one's more of a technical skills.

101
00:04:36.638 --> 00:04:39.241
We want to show you guys
the really important parts,

102
00:04:39.241 --> 00:04:42.033
the stuff in Azure SQL that
you're gonna use everyday.

103
00:04:42.033 --> 00:04:44.758
When you study for a certification,
you learn a lot of great stuff.

104
00:04:44.758 --> 00:04:47.023
A lot of great technologies that
sometimes you don't implement, right?

105
00:04:47.023 --> 00:04:48.822
That just aren't used by a lot of people.

106
00:04:48.822 --> 00:04:50.865
We're gonna focus on the details, right?

107
00:04:50.865 --> 00:04:53.816
The stuff that you know you're
going to use every single day.

108
00:04:53.816 --> 00:04:55.233
So it's all great content.

109
00:04:55.233 --> 00:04:57.855
I'm always excited about
the tech skills shows that we do.

110
00:04:57.855 --> 00:05:01.523
I know they don't lead to a certification
but what they do lead to is job success.

111
00:05:01.523 --> 00:05:04.659
You really learn that skill, and
you're ready to get out there and

112
00:05:04.659 --> 00:05:07.861
implement it and it's not some
fringe topic that you may never see.

113
00:05:07.861 --> 00:05:10.692
>> Awesome, well it sounds like
a really practical course, so

114
00:05:10.692 --> 00:05:13.808
anybody that's interested in Azure SQL,
this is the place to be.

115
00:05:13.808 --> 00:05:15.419
These upcoming episodes
are going to be awesome.

116
00:05:15.419 --> 00:05:19.358
Weâ€™re really working hard to
create great content with that, so

117
00:05:19.358 --> 00:05:21.803
hopefully we'll see you in the future.

118
00:05:21.803 --> 00:05:22.303
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explore and explain some of the foundational concepts and workings of Azure SQL. They start by defining why you might decide to implement a hosted database in Azure SQL vs an on-premise solution; detailing some of the benefits of moving to Azure SQL. Then they describe some of the more advanced benefits of using Azure SQL like using Resource Groups, Geo-Restore, Point-In-Time Restore, and Self-Service Restore. Finally they take a look at the performance tiers as well as Database Throughput Units or DTUs.
episodes.title: Introduction to Azure SQL

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through creating databases using Microsoft Azure SQL. They begin with creating a simple, blank database; taking you step-by-step from start to finish. Then they explore some ways of importing an already existing database into Azure SQL.
episodes.title: Creating Your First Database

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel detail ways in which you can connect your Azure SQL database to a SQL client/manager. First they start with connecting Azure SQL to Microsoft's Visual Studio. Then they show you how to download, install, and configure Microsoft's SQL Management Studio.
episodes.title: Connecting Your Client

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the concept and implementation of Azure SQL Elastic Pools. They begin by defining what an Elastic Pool is and how/why they might benefit your environment. Then they show you how to create an Elastic Pool, all the while informing your setup choices as to get the best bang for your buck.
episodes.title: Using Elastic Pools

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don walk you through a few different ways in which you can migrate your on-premise database into Azure SQL. They start by showing you how to perform a scripted import using T-SQL from within Visual Studio. Then they demonstrate a migration using the SQL Management Studio Azure Deployment Wizard. Finally they perform a migration using BACPACs and monitor the progress of the migration.
episodes.title: Migrating Databases to Azure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don show you how to create Tables and input data into an Azure SQL database. First they demonstrate creating tables in SQL and dive into some of the information that will be necessary for proper table creation and functionality. Then they show you how to create data to populate the tables as well as queries to retrieve data.
episodes.title: Tables and Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explore automation of tasks in Azure SQL. They start by explaining how to enable automation beginning with the SQL Server Agent. Then they jump into Azure and create an Automation Account which will be needed to create automated tasks for SQL. Here they introduce you to Runbooks which works inside of PowerShell to create the scripts for automation. Then they upload, test, publish, and schedule a task.
episodes.title: Azure Automation

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel take a look at exporting data from your Azure SQL database. First they talk about when you might need to export an entire database and then walk you through the methods to that end. Then they discuss how you might export pieces of data like tables from your database. They show you a few formats that you might export the data as such as XML, CSV, and even into an Excel spreadsheet.
episodes.title: Exporting Data

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel describe and demonstrate how you can optimize your SQL databases by implementing indexes. They start off by explaining what an index is, the two main types of indexes (clustered and non-clustered) and how it can benefit your database. They also explain when NOT to use indexes.
episodes.title: Implementing Indexes

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel continue explaining how to implement indexes and here they pick back up by looking at the Azure Index Advisor. The Index Advisor will help you optimize your databases by suggesting indexes. They also look at Query Performance Insight tool and how to perform index maintenance.
episodes.title: Implementing Indexes Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel talk about database maintenance tasks in Azure SQL. They begin with the demarcation of duties; what tasks are being handled by Microsoft(backups, replication, consistency checks) and what tasks are handled by the customer(index creation/maintenance, data partitioning, and statistics). Finally they take a close look at database statistics; specifically creating, maintaining, and removing statistics. Also covered is Asynchronous Statistics.
episodes.title: Database Maintenance

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel show you how to keep a watchful eye on your Azure SQL deployment by utilizing monitoring services. They start by exploring the Database Health check and looking at database events in the Azure SQL portal. They then show you how to monitor your database size and setup alerts to warn you when an action needs to be taken. Lastly, they demonstrate the Dynamic Management Views(DMVs) which works querying the database for specific information in real time.
episodes.title: Monitoring Azure SQL

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Don explain the concept and practice of scaling a Azure SQL database. Here they are going to show you how to scale your databases up or down, which can save costs, depending on your need. They also talk about scaling automation, which can help you scale your environment up and/or down at times when you know performance needs are going to change.
episodes.title: Scaling Up/Down

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel dive into availability and recovery features provided by Azure SQL, here specifically looking at Geographical Redundancy. They start off by describing what geo-redundancy is and they two different types of geo-replication (Standard and Active) that's available in Azure SQL. Then they show you how to implement both types and even how to perform a failover test to make sure everything is working in case of an outage.
episodes.title: Geographical Redundancy

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain how to recover data from a backup in case of an accidental deletion or corruption of data by implementing a self-service restore. They explain how Azure SQL takes backups and replicates data and then move into performing a restore from the Azure SQL portal as well as by using the PowerShell.
episodes.title: Self-Service Restore

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel take a look at securing your Azure SQL database by controlling access through the network. First they show you how to configure the server level firewall through the Azure web portal as well as with PowerShell. They also cover securing multiple databases that share a server by creating rules with Transact SQL.
episodes.title: Controlling Network Access

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain the different user account and roles implemented in Azure SQL. They being by opening the Azure Web Portal and setting up a server management administrator and describing all the possible roles available which grants permissions. Then they look at creating regular database users by using T-SQL with the SQL Management Studio and configure the default database roles, again for access permissions.
episodes.title: Users and Roles

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel dive into database permissions and schemas. They start by discussing database permissions and how they can be set on database objects like tables which will allow you to have very fine control over who can access that table. This leads them into describing setting permissions on users vs. groups/roles and when you would do one over the other. Finally they explain the idea of schemas which enables you to basically create a template to set permissions with an overarching scope.
episodes.title: Permissions and Schemas

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel explain server and database auditing when using Azure SQL. First they go over how to enable server level auditing, taking you step-by-step through the Azure web portal. Next they show you how to enable auditing at the database level which can have certain advantages over auditing the server. They also explore the threat detection system to help secure your Azure SQL deployments.
episodes.title: Database Auditing

episodes.description: In this episode, Don and Daniel go over deploying applications to Azure. They begin by showing you how to deploy a fully functional web app from start to finish, all while using the Azure Marketplace, prebuilt application profiles (specifically mojoPortal). They also show you how you can develop your own app by using Visual Studio Community edition and connecting to Azure with your in-house apps.
episodes.title: Deploying Applications
